He's given us a new name, a new identity. I think this evening about the wonderful truth that as believers, as Christians, our identity is in Christ. Our identity is in Christ. But the reality is that first, the primary identity for each child of God is that I'm a Christian. I belong to Christ. And he says, not only will I give him to eat of the hidden manna, I'll give him a white stone and then the stone a name written, which no man knoweth, saving he that receiveth it. I wonder if you remember when you first got saved and maybe somebody said something like this to you, now you're a Christian. Now you're a Christian. And I don't know if that was said to you or what significance it would have had immediately. But as you look back and you begin to understand that, it's significant. I'm a Christian. What does it mean to be a Christian? We use the word in the New Testament, saint. One who is in Christ and whom Christ dwells. Wow, it's amazing. I remember when my dad got saved. Here's what some of the people said. Well, Chris got religion, it will wear off. No, he got a new name. He got saved, he got born again. And you know what? Other people may not have understood that new name Christian, but he understood. And tonight, when we acknowledge the fact that we've been saved by the grace of God and we've been pardoned and we have forgiveness and we have a new name that's written, that I am a Christian and the world may not understand that. The world might think, oh, that just means you're religious. No, it doesn't mean I'm religious. I told a man I was knocking on his door and he answered the door. I think Tim, maybe Ronnie was with me knocking door. And he said, oh, I don't like religion. I said, neither do I. And he looked at me like I was crazy because I had just announced that I was from Fellowship Baptist Church. I don't like religion, why? Because religion condemns. It's a relationship with the Lord Jesus Christ that gives life and purpose. And we understand it tonight, but notice it says, which no man knoweth saving he that receiveth it. You try to explain to lost relatives and lost coworkers what Christ did for you and they don't get it because they don't have it. Does that make sense? And we get it because we have it. And we can rejoice tonight. Listen, the church in Pergamos, they were doing some things. They were a light in a dark place. They were faithful. But there was some compromise that was creeping in. There was some corruption that was coming in. And Jesus says, hey, listen, repent. It's there. I know it. I see it. I'm telling you, there are some that are there that hold the doctrine of Balaam and the doctrine of the Nicolaitans. And if you don't repent, I'm gonna come and judge. This evening, as we evaluate the church in Pergamos, we can take this admonition in charge and we can say, hey, listen, we need to keep on doing right and we need to know the principles of God's word so that we can resist and avoid compromise so that we can continue to have the blessing of God upon our lives individually, in our families and in our church so that God would be glorified. Let's pray. Father, we love you. We thank you for loving us. Thank you for your word. I thank you for this letter, the church in Pergamos. I thank you, God, for what you have revealed to us through it. And I pray that you'd help us to take heed. I pray that tonight, Lord, you would help us to evaluate and examine our own lives in light of this letter to the church in Pergamos. Lord, help us as we acknowledge tonight that the temptation for compromise will always exist, but God, help us to stay true to you and to your word. Help us, Lord, to resist and avoid compromise so that we might continue to have the blessing of God upon our lives. Well, thank you for every decision made for it's in Christ's name we pray, amen.
